text: For aqueous polymer blends, stable fibre formation often occurs when total polymer loading is 10-22 wt%. Below this, beads appear; above this, viscosity can limit jet stability. Humidity 30-50% is a common window for repeatable morphologies.

In WPU/gelatin electrospinning, voltage 12-20 kV and tip-to-collector distance 12-18 cm are typical. Increasing voltage tends to reduce fibre diameter, while increasing flow rate increases diameter and bead formation.

Cationic additives such as PEI can enhance antimicrobial activity but may reduce cytocompatibility at high loadings. Practical ranges are often 0.5-3 wt% relative to total solution, with optimisation required for balancing activity and viability.

Humidity 25-45% often improves uniformity for many aqueous systems, whereas humidity above 55% can increase bead density and broaden the diameter distribution. Flow rate 0.3-1.0 mL/h is typical for lab-scale syringes.
Allantoin and hyaluronic acid are frequently used to improve skin compatibility. Additive loading is commonly below 3 wt% total to avoid disrupting fibre formation.
